nodes.text: Question: Have intergenerational income mobility trends declined in the United States for children born 1971–1993, i.e., is the US no longer a land of opportunity?
Rank-based measures of intergenerational mobility (correlation between parent and child income percentile ranks) have remained stable across recent birth cohorts
Administrative earnings and tax records were used to construct linked parent-child samples covering children born 1971–1993

Two samples: a population-based linked sample (1980–1993 cohorts, parents measured as mean income ages 15–19) and an SOI stratified sample (1971–1982 cohorts) with sampling weights and ~95% or ~88% linkage coverage

Mobility measured via rank-rank regressions (child rank on parent rank), college attendance gradients (college indicator regressed on parent rank), transition matrices, and consolidated series combining age 26, age 30 and college measures
Empirical finding: rank-rank slope estimates are approximately 0.30 for 1971–1982 cohorts with small standard errors and show no trend
Empirical finding: college attendance gradient (gap between lowest- and highest-income families) is essentially constant at ~74.5% for 1984–1989 cohorts and falls slightly to ~69.2% by 1993
Empirical finding: quintile transition probabilities are stable across cohorts (e.g., probability of moving from bottom parent quintile to top child quintile is 8.4% in 1971 and 9.0% in 1986)
Claim: Income inequality (marginal distributions) increased substantially over the sample period as measured by Gini coefficients and top 1 percent shares
Evidence: increases in parental and child Gini coefficients and top 1 percent income shares in the sample match prior estimates and CPS trends

Conclusion: Although rank-based mobility is stable, increased inequality has enlarged the absolute consequences of the birth lottery so differences in expected incomes by parental rank are larger today

Claim: Intergenerational mobility varies substantially across US areas and these cross-sectional regional differences are large and persistent (e.g., bottom-to-top probability 4% in parts of Southeast versus over 12% in Mountain states)

Evidence: Area-level estimates for 1980–1985 cohorts show bottom-to-top probabilities ranging from ~4% in some Southeast areas to >12% in Mountain states and stable regional rank-rank slopes and college gradients across cohorts

Method/assumption: Constructed consolidated mobility series for 1971–1993 by scaling age-26 income gradients (factor 1.12) and college gradients (factor 0.40) to match age-30 income gradients and forecasting age-30 mobility under assumption these scalings are constant

Result: The consolidated series is essentially flat; estimated trend in rank-rank slope from 1971–1993 is -0.0006 per year with 95% upper bound 0.0008, implying at most a 0.27 percent per year rise in persistence

Limitation: Data end in 2012 so child income at age 30 cannot be observed beyond 1982 cohorts; forecasts rely on assumption that college and age-26 gradients are constant multiples of age-30 gradients
